data.question: What is the difference between agile software development and traditional software development?
items: At the level of actual software development, there isn't a difference. Both produce code aimed at solving a problem
Traditional development focuses more on plans and process while agile focuses more on outcomes and value
Agile development focuses more on plans and process while traditional development focuses more on outcomes and value
Traditional development is much more disciplined than agile because of the distinct phases
data.explanation: B is correct. Agile development is usually more disciplined (with respect to outcomes, not process) than traditional development.

data.question:
Which of the following are benefits of using Scrum?
A. Adaptability
B. Continuous development
C. Sustainable pace
D. Customer centric
E. High Velocity
F. Motivation
G. Clear requirements
items: All of the above
A,B,C,D
B,C,D,E,G
A,C,D,E,F

data.question: How does the Scrum Guidance Body (SGB) contribute to scalability?
items: It doesn't, it only provides documentation and guidance
The SGB determines how Scrum scales within the organization
The SGB recommends when to hold various meetings that are part of Scrum
The SGB documents the rules for scalability

data.question: Which of the following is NOT a Scrum principle?
items: Iterative Development
Collaboration
Inspect and adopt
Self-organizing teams
data.explanation: This is a little tricky. The SBOK included Inspect and Adapt as part of empirical process control.

data.question: What is value-based prioritization?
items: The priority assigned to a user story by the Development Team
The priority assigned by the Product Owner
The priority assigned that represents business value
The priority agreed by negotiation between the Product Owner and the Development Team
data.explanation: While the Product Owner does assign priority based on value, that isn't really the answer to the question. C is correct.

data.question:
The business case documents the business justification for the Scrum project. What else does the business case provide?
A. Basis for project scope
B. Estimated costs
C. Options
D. Risks
items: A and B
B and C
A and D
All of the above

data.question: What is true of the two aspects of the Review & Retrospect phase?
items: The Review focuses on lessons learned; the Retrospect focuses on customer value
The Review focuses on customer value; the Retrospect focuses on lessons learned
The Review focuses on process improvement; the Retrospect focuses on demonstration, inspect and adapt
The Review focuses on demonstration, inspect and adapt; the Retrospect focuses on process improvement

data.question: Which of the following is NOT considered as part of the Plan and Estimate phase?
items: Create the Sprint Backlog
Plan the Release
Create User Stories
Estimate Tasks
data.explanation: Release planning is part of the Initiate phase. B is correct.

data.question: What is the purpose of the Create the Project Vision?
items: Identify who will use or benefit from the products produced by the product
Make sure the requisite meetings and artifacts are produced before the project starts
Make sure the project is viable before it starts
Identify the project deliverables and the value provided

data.question:
What is true about Gap Analysis?
A. Identify current state
B. Document target state
C. Determine Scrum processes required to achieve the target
D. Determine a possible path to achieve the target
items: A,B,C
A,B,D
B,C,D
All of the above

data.question: Which one of the following is NOT a characteristic of a good Scrum Master?
items: Good facilitator
Most knowledgeable person about Scrum
Effective listening
Motivator and coach
data.explanation: While it's important the Scrum Master be knowledgeable about Scrum, it's entirely likely that for early projects the Scrum Master won't be any more or less familiar with Scrum than anyone else on the Team. The important skills are the others listed, not specifically Scrum knowledge. B is correct.

data.question: Why is it important to identify stakeholders early in the development effort?
items: Stakeholders are required to be engaged throughout the project lifecycle
Vendors may have an interest in the outcomes, so this has to be identified
It's not important to identify stakeholders early, as long as they are identified before development starts
It is critical to identify everyone that has a vested interest in the outcomes of the development effort as soon as possible so that their input is considered before it's too late
data.explanation: While you could argue that everyone has some vested interest in the project outcomes, the SBOK is clear that the stakeholders only include customers, users, and sponsors. A is correct.

data.question:
Which of the following are some of the key skills for the Scrum Team?
A. Fast programming
B. Self-motivated
C. Good debugging
D. Responsible
E. Language lawyer
F. Works well with others
G. Independent thinking
items: A,B,C,D
B,D,F,G
B,E,F,G
A,D,E,F
data.explanation: While A, C and E might be important for some people on the projects, they aren't the core skills needed by every member of the cross-functional Scrum Team. B is correct.

data.question: What is the purpose of the Develop Epic(s) process?
items: Create user stories that serve as a high-level baseline on scope and requirements
Assure that there is a way to formulate a complete set of user story acceptance criteria
Estimate and commit user stories
Epic stories are refined and prioritized by the Development Team to form the basis of the Sprint Backlog
data.explanation: Epics are high-level unrefined user stories that need to be refined / broken down into simpler implementable user stories. Epics are more complex (because they are unrefined) than the user stories used for development. If it's not in the Epic it won't be in the resulting user stories crafted from the Epic. This is part of the definition of scope. A is correct.

data.question: How are the items in the Product Backlog organized and prioritized?
items: It is solely the Product Owner's responsibility to put items into the Product Backlog and determine their priority
The Product Owner works with stakeholders to develop not only the items included in the Product Backlog, but also their priority
The Scrum Master runs and facilitates the various meetings where the items for the Product Backlog are considered and prioritized

The entire Scrum team works with project stakeholders to discuss the requirements for the project. With full information the team then works to be sure the items included in the Product Backlog are assigned the proper priority to deliver the maximum value

data.question: What is the purpose of the Conduct Release Planning process?
items: It is one of the last things the team does to get ready to release and deploy the finished products from the project
Release planning is conducted near the end of each Sprint before the results from the effort are transitioned to the customers/users
Release planning makes sure the products that developed one or more Sprints are properly bundled into a Release Package to maximize the business value
Release planning starts before any products are developed to help focus the Scrum Team to provide the maximum business value as quickly as possible
data.explanation: D is correct. Release planning begins at the beginning of a project to establish the MMF (minimum marketable features) required before there is sufficient functionality to generate business value. Release planning then continues throughout the project as customer requirements and changes are taken into account.

data.question: Which of the following is a simple valid user story?
items: Mary needs to be able to enter expenses into the XYA Form

ABC Company sales people (aka mobile workers) need to be able to view client information on company supplied tablets while on the road so that they have up-to-date information about outstanding (or open) orders (i.e., orders that have not been shipped) before meeting with the client
As a PDQ Executive I need to be able to view executive data but only if it is in a secure location because the data is sensitive
As an ABC employee I need to be able to log into my system
data.explanation: A doesn't include a measure of done or acceptance. C and D are more epic than user story. B is correct even though it's not formally written in the presented format (As a… etc.).

data.question: What is true about all of the methods used to estimate user stories?
items: The techniques help develop precision regarding the effort required to turn a user story into working code
User story estimation is a necessary first step, but much more work is needed to be able to determine the real effort that will be required
All of the estimation techniques produce relative estimates of complexity and/or effort based on consensus
The estimation techniques are a good starting point, but it's up to the Product Owner to verify that they fit the customer expectations

data.question: What is an output from Approve, Estimate and Commit User Stories?
items: Basis for a Sprint Backlog
Basis for the Product Backlog
Entries for the Sprint Burndown Chart
Epic stories

data.question: When is the task planning meeting run?
items: At the beginning of each project
At the beginning of the Refine Epic(s) process
At the beginning of Estimate, Approve and Commit User Stories
At the beginning of each Sprint
data.explanation: D is correct. The Task Planning Meeting is also known as the Sprint Planning Meeting.

data.question:
Why is it important to write the user stories on something no bigger than a 3 x 5 card?
A. Keeps the stories short
B. Facilitate collaboration
C. Transparency
items: A and B
B and C
A and C
All of the above

data.question: Task estimation meetings are used to estimate what?
items: Risk
Completion dates
Cost
Resources needed/required

data.question: What is the Sprint Backlog?
items: It's used with the Product Owner to determine the work required to complete the project
It is the list of user stories used by the development team
It is the stories left over from the previous Sprint
It is a progress estimation and tracking tool

data.question:
Which of the following are sprint tracking metrics?
A. Derived business value
B. Cost of developing the stories in the sprint
C. Time spent developing the stories in the sprint
D. Number of user stories completed in the sprint
E. Velocity
items: All of the above
A,B,C
C,D,E
A,D,E

data.question: What happens during the Create Deliverables process?
items: Acceptance testing
Document business benefits
Finish a lessons learned report
Do the work of the Sprint

data.question: What is Test Driven Development (TDD)?
items: A way of automating testing after the code is complete
A way of automating the development of tests
Develop story-based tests before writing the code to implement the story
Develop epic-based test to help verify that epics are properly refined into user stories

data.question: Why is refactoring important?
items: Re-think the code
Break the code in factors
It is part of design patterns
Improve code quality and maintainability

data.question: The ___________ participates in the daily standup and the ________ facilitates it.
items: Scrum Master and Team Lead
Team leads (plural) and Product Owner
Development Team and Product Owner
Development Team and Scrum Master

data.question: What happens during the daily standup?
items: Team shares status, immediate plans and risks
Answers questions
Decisions are made
Nothing really happens, the team just updates the Product Owner
data.explanation: Status: what I did yesterday; immediate plans: what I plan to do today; risks: impediments or obstacles. A is correct.

data.question:
Which of the following statements is true?
A. Teams should be co-located
B. Distributed development teams are hard to manage
items: A is true, B is false
A is false, B is true
Both are true
Both are false

data.question: When does grooming take place?
items: Only before new development starts (before a sprint begins)
After new development has started (within a sprint)
It's up to the product owner to do the grooming whenever it's needed
Both before and after new development starts
data.explanation: Grooming takes place before development begins as part of the Sprint Planning meeting and anytime during the sprint if the team discovers they need input from stakeholders (or the product owner).

data.question: When is it critical to groom the backlog?
items: It's up to the Product Owner
All stories are subject to grooming
It's critical to groom Epics before User Stories
As stories move up the Product Backlog, it's more important to groom them (i.e., the ones near the top of the backlog)
data.explanation: While the Product Owner can groom the Product Backlog at any time, it is really critical as stories near the top of the backlog, before the stories are picked up by a development team. D is correct.

data.question: How does Scrum scale?
items: How Scrum scales depends on whether the overall project reports to a project or program management office
Scrum doesn't scale, team size is limited
For really large projects Scrum scales using a Scrum of Scrum of Scrums
The only way to scale is the Scrum of Scrums
data.explanation: For really large projects, even a Scrum of Scrums might not be enough. C is correct.

data.question: If there is a Scrum of Scrums, what is the BEST answer to why it isn't time-boxed?
items: There are too many people attending the Scrum of Scrums. Since the number of teams represented is unknown, the time can't be constrained
Because that is what the SBOK says
It could be time-boxed if the participants want
To allow time to work out any problems or challenges presented

data.question:
Which of the following are reasons for the Sprint Review Meeting?
A. Allows the team to learn lessons for process improvement
B. Demonstrate user stories that are done
C. Get stakeholders involved
D. Allow the Product Owner to confirm user stories are done
E. Identify issues with a plan to resolve them
items: A,B,C
D only
B,C,D,E
A and E

data.question: What happens to rejected deliverables?
items: They are removed from the Product Backlog
They are returned to the Product Backlog
They are reworked in the next Sprint for this team
They are reworked in the next Sprint for a different team

data.question: The Explorer-Shopper-Vacationer-Prisoner evaluation focuses on:
items: Good example of what doesn't work (i.e., what not to do in the next Sprint)
Lessons learned
Allows stakeholders an opportunity to register engagement
Team engagement

data.question:
Which of the following are valid Scrum metrics?
A. Self-assessment
B. Story-point business case alignment percentage
C. Team velocity
D. Predicted vs actual
E. Hours per story point
F. Ratings from stakeholders
G. Done success rate
items: A,B,C,D,G
A,C,D,F,G
B,E,F
All of the above

data.question: What are Agreed Actionable Improvements?
items: Improvements the team has agreed to implement in the next Sprint
They are entries in the log the Scrum Master maintains for consideration by the Scrum Guidance Body
They form the basis for lessons learned
List of items the team will address to improve process and performance

data.question:
Who, besides the Development Team, must attend the Sprint Retrospect meeting?
A. Scrum Master
B. Product Owner
C. Stakeholders
items: A only
B only
A and B
All of the above
data.explanation: The Scrum Master facilitates the meeting. The Product Owner MAY attend but is not required. A is correct.

data.question: What is the purpose of a Sprint?
items: Complete an increment of code
Develop code to ship
Complete code that is potentially shippable
Work on the stories the team committed

data.question: When is code shippable?
items: When it's done
At the end of the Sprint
When the Product Owner says so
When the acceptance criteria for each committed story has been met

data.question: What is a Pilot Plan?
items: Another name for the Communications Plan
An optional plan that maps out how each released increment is piloted and deployed
Provides a sanity check to make sure the deliverables are targeted at the correct user base
Defines how the output from each will be used

data.question:
Which of the following is true about deployment methods?
A. Based on established minimum functionality by the Product Owner
B. Highly dependent on organizational culture, methods and experience
C. Integrated with formal release and deployment processes to manage risk
items: All of the above
A and B
A and C
B and C

data.question: During testing the ___ and the ____ facilitate communications consistent with the Communications Plan.
items: Development Team and Scrum Master
Scrum Master and Product Owner
Core Team and Product Sponsor
Product Owner and Product Sponsor

data.question: What is true about the Project Retrospect?
items: Attended by just the core team
Attended by all project team members
Is a more formal meeting than the Sprint Retrospect
May be time-boxed, depending on the organization
data.explanation: Depending on the size and complexity of the project, the Project Retrospect is also attended by the Chief Product Owner and Chief Scrum Master. B is correct.

data.question:
Which of the following is true about the Project Retrospect?
A. The same techniques used in the Sprint Retrospect apply
B. The Scrum Guidance Body assures the lessons learned are incorporated into future projects
items: A is true
B is true
Both are true
Both are false

data.question: What happens to the product backlog when the project is closed?
items: It is never complete or closed until and unless the product(s) it represents are retired from service
It is archived as a part of project documentation
Ownership changes from the Product Owner to the Scrum Guidance Body until the next version or work increment is authorized
Nothing, once the product ships, the Product Backlog isn't needed
